questions.question_text: A network engineer must optimize a Cisco ACI multi-pod deployment. Both pods are using the same pod policy group. The customer requirement is to avoid inter-pod traffic loss in case of planned or unplanned spine reload. Which action accomplishes this goal?

discussion.content:
C : 
https://community.cisco.com/t5/data-center-and-cloud-blogs/aci-multi-pods-caveats-and-considerations/ba-p/3837927

Selected Answer: C
This is because by default the redistributiin metric is 63 for ISIS and lowering it down as CBP is recommended if spine rebooted planned or unplanned.

Selected Answer: D
I vote for D. 
C is not right because adjusting IS-IS metrics affects intra-pod route preferences but does not directly address inter-pod route availability during spine reloads.

Selected Answer: D
To ensure minimal traffic disruption during a planned or unplanned spine reload in a multi-pod ACI deployment, the correct action is:

Configure all spines as Route Reflectors in the BGP Route Reflector Policy.

This configuration ensures that all spines have a complete view of the network topology and can forward traffic to the appropriate destination, even if one or more spines are down or undergoing a reload. By distributing the routing information across multiple spines, the network becomes more resilient and can tolerate failures without significant impact.

Selected Answer: D
I think that would be D, because the question says "traffic loss in case of pllaned or umpllaned spine reload", It say spine not spines. So both spines should be route reflectos.

Selected Answer: C
Prior to 5.0(1): Fabric > Fabric Policies > Policies > Pod > ISIS Policy Default > ISIS metric for redistributed routes
From 5.0(1): System > System Settings > ISIS Policy > ISIS metric for redistributed routes

Selected Answer: C
This ensures that when new spine switch is introduced (booting up), or during upgrades/reboot of spine, the spine is not in the forwarding path to external destinations until the full configuration of the spine is completed and the default metric is changed to the lower metric (recommended to 32, default 63).
(Fabric>Fabric Policies>Policies>POD>ISIS Policy default)
*Traffic loss for Multi-Pod traffic after a Spine reboot (BugID CSCvd75131)

Selected Answer: A
Very difficult question but option A would probably be the more viable answer for me, as the COOP database will help optimize the traffic. The BGP Route Reflector (answer D) will simply reflect the routes learned from boarder leaf's the rest of the fabric to the rest of the fabric. COOP database on the other hand will use the IPN's to optimise traffic internally. Anyway im not 100 % sure!

choices.D: Configure all spines as Route Reflectors in the BGP Route Reflector Policy.
choices.C: Configure a lower IS-IS metric for redistributed routes in ISIS Policy.
choices.A: Configure the COOP type as compatible in COOP Group Policy.
choices.B: Configure MACsec in the MACsec Fabric Interface Policy.

questions.question_text: An engineer wants to configure Cisco ACI switches to use authenticated ZMQ when communicating with the proxy spine. Which configuration allows MD5 ZMQ messages only?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/dcn/aci/apic/5x/security-configuration/cisco-apic-security-configuration-guide-release-52x/protocol-authentication-52x.html

Selected Answer: A
There are 2 choices, Compatible Type and Strict Type. Compatible Type accepts both MD5 authenticated and non-authenticated ZMQ connections, whereas Strict Type only allows MD5 authenticated ZMQ connections.

choices.D: COOP Group policy in compatible mode
choices.A: COOP Group policy in strict mode

choices.C: Add a second path to the logical interface profile of the existing L3Out.
choices.B: Add a second interface to the external domain to the existing L3Out.
choices.A: Add a second OSPF interface profile to the logical interface profile.
choices.D: Add a second subnet to the external EPG to the existing L3Out.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
In Cisco ACI, an L3Out is used to provide Layer 3 connectivity between the ACI fabric and external networks. When adding a second link to the existing L3Out for redundancy or additional connectivity, you must configure a new path in the logical interface profile associated with the L3Out. This ensures that traffic from both Core-1 and Core-2 routers can be routed through the same L3Out, maintaining consistent connectivity.

Refer to the exhibit. A tenant is configured with a single L3Out and a single-homed link to the core router called Core-1. An engineer must add a second link to the L3Out that connects to the Core-2 router. Which action allows traffic from Core-2 to BL-1002 to have the same connectivity as the traffic from Core-1 to BL-1001?

choices.C: Add a static range to VMware/west-VLP.
choices.D: Associate VMware/west-AEP with a physical domain.
choices.A: Configure VMware/west-AEP with the correct vCenter credentials.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
When associating an EPG with a VMM domain in Cisco ACI, the APIC automatically creates a corresponding port group in VMware vCenter. However, the VLAN pool associated with the VMM domain must include a valid VLAN range for this process to succeed. If no VLANs are defined in the VLAN pool (in this case, west-VLP), the port group creation fails because there are no VLANs available for assignment.

Selected Answer: B

The only solution is A. Because there is already a VLAN pool assigned. The only thing what is missing are the credentials.

An engineer needs to deploy a leaf access port policy group in ACI Fabric to support the following requirements:
✑ Control the amount of application data flowing into the system
✑ Allow the newly connected device to auto-negotiate link speed with the leaf switch
Which two ACI policies must be configured to achieve these requirements? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
A. link level policy
D. ingress data plane policing policy

Selected Answer: AD
A and D are correct.
Fabric > Access Policies > Policies > Link Level Policy
A.Link Level Policy (auto negotiation - Off / On / On - Enforce)

Fabric > Access Policies > Policies > Data Plane Policing Policy 
B. Ingress data plane policing

Selected Answer: AD
Link Level Policies
You can configure link level policies, which are a type of access policy. 

Data Plane Policing
Use data plane policing (DPP) to manage bandwidth consumption on ACi. DPP policies can apply to egress traffic, ingress traffic, or both. 

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/dcn/aci/apic/5x/security-configuration/cisco-apic-security-configuration-guide-release-52x/data-plane-policing-52x.html#:~:text=Use%20data%20plane%20policing%20%28DPP%29%20to%20manage%20bandwidth,monitors%20the%20data%20rates%20for%20a%20particular%20interface.
